titlestmt.titleproper: A Finding Aid to the Grace Borgenicht Gallery Records, circa 1953-1996, in the Archives of American Art AAA.gracborg
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Sarah Mundy
titlestmt.sponsor: Funding for the processing of this collection was provided by the Smithsonian Institution Collections Care and Preservation Fund

note.p: This finding aid is associated with a MARC collection-level record 208897.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2015-06-30T15:44-0400

did.abstract: The records of New York City Grace Borgenicht Gallery date from circa 1953 to 1996 and measure 18 linear feet. The records include administrative files, correpsondence, financial and legal records, exhibition files, printed material, two scrapbooks, and photographic negatives of artwork. The majority of the collection consists of artists' files.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The records of New York City Grace Borgenicht Gallery date from circa 1953 to 1996 and measure 18 linear feet. The records include administrative files, correpsondence, financial and legal records, exhibition files, printed material, two scrapbooks, and photographic negatives of artwork. The majority of the collection consists of artists' files.

Administrative files focus on advertising, events, gallery renovation, artists' insurance, and writings about the gallery. Correspondence concerns galleries, artists, works of art, and gallery prints and includes correspondence with the Library of Congress, Hokin Gallery, and Raab Gallery in Berlin. Exhibition files are found for exhibitions of Milton Avery, Paul Burlin, Stuart Davis, and Wolf Kahn, and several artists from Germany, Japan, Korea, Mexico, and Canada, as well as for international art fairs. Artists' files mainly contain correspondence with galleries and patrons regarding the artists and their work, and with artists. Files are found for Milton Avery, Charles Biederman, Ilya Bolotowsky, Martin Chirino, Stuart Davis, Jose De Rivera, Roy Gussow, Philip Grausman, and Wolf Kahn, among many others. Financial and legal records include sales and operations ledgers, artists' contracts, and documents concerning arts organizations. Printed materials consist of exhibition announcements and catalogs. Two scrapbooks include clippings and other printed materials. Also found are photographic negatives of artwork.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: The collection is arranged as 8 series.

list.item: Series 1: Administrative Records, 1970-1995 (0.2 linear feet; Box 1)
Series 2: Correspondence, circa 1950s-1995 (2 linear feet; Boxes 1-3)
Series 3: Exhibition Files, circa 1970-1996 (1.3 linear feet; Boxes 3-4)
Series 4: Artists Files, circa 1950s-1995 (11.2 linear feet; Boxes 4-13, 16-22)
Series 5: Financial and Legal Records, 1953-1995 (1.4 linear feet; Boxes 13-15)
Series 6: Printed Material, circa 1950s-1995 (0.8 linear feet; Box 15)
Series 7: Scrapbooks, circa 1950s-circa 1980s (0.3 linear feet; Box 23)
Series 8: Photographic Materials, circa 1950s-circa 1980s (0.8 linear feet; Boxes 24-25)

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use note
userestrict.p: The Grace Borgenicht Gallery records are owned by the Archives of American Art, Smithsonian Institution. Literary rights as possessed by the donor have been dedicated to public use for research, study, and scholarship. The collection is subject to all copyright laws.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition note
acqinfo.p: The collection was donated in 1996 by owner Grace Borgenicht Brandt.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: In May 1951 Grace Borgenicht Brandt (1915-2001) opened the Grace Borgenicht Gallery on 57th Street in New York City with an exhibition of Jimmy Ernst. At that time, the gallery was one of a handful that represented contemporary American artists. Jimmy Ernst, Milton Avery, Ilya Bolotowsky, Edward Corbett, Jose de Rivera, Roy Gussow, Wolf Kahn, and Gabor Peterdi were among the artists represented by the gallery.

The gallery held multiple exhibitions for individual artists such as Milton Avery, Wolf Kahn, Paul Burlin, and Stuart Davis. Although Borgenicht's main focus was American contemporary artists, the gallery also held several exhibitions featuring artists from Canada, Germany, Japan, Korea, and Mexico.
The Grace Borgenicht Gallery closed in 1995.

processinfo.head: Processing Information note
processinfo.p: The collection was processed to a minimal level and a finding aid prepared by Sarah Mundy in 2015, with funding provided by the Smithsonian Institution Collections Care and Preservation Fund. The Archives of American Art has implemented minimal processing tactics when possible to increase information about and access to more of our collections.

Minimal processing included arrangement to the series, subseries, and folder levels. Generally, items within folders were simply verified with folder titles, but not arranged further. Folders within boxes may not be numbered. The collections was rehoused in archival containers and folders, but not all staples and clips were removed.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation note
prefercite.p: Grace Borgenicht Gallery records, circa 1953-1996. Archives of American Art, Smithsonian Institution.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Archival Materials note
relatedmaterial.p: Also found at the Archives of American Art is an oral history interview with Grace Borgenicht Brandt conducted by Dorothy Seckler on January 10, 1963.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access note
accessrestrict.p: Use of original papers requires an appointment and is limited to the Washington, D.C. Research Center.

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Materials note
separatedmaterial.p: Also found in the Archives are papers loaned by Grace Borgenicht Brandt in 1963 for microfilming on Reel D112, including 72 letters from artists Leonard Baskin, Edward Corbett, Sidney Gordin, Wolf Kahn and Elbert Weinberg, to gallery director Grace Borgenicht (Grace Borgenicht Brandt), regarding their work, work in progress, travels, exhibition plans and other activities. Also included are Brandt's resume and a photograph of her.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Files concern advertising, private events, gallery renovation plans, artists' insurance, and writings about the gallery.

did.unittitle: Writings and Notes About the Grace Borgenicht Gallery

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Correspondence includes general chronological correspondence, letters with the Hokin Gallery and Raab Gallery, and correspondence regarding gallery prints for the Library of Congress. Artists and works of art are typically discussed in general correspondence.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: There are exhibition files for Milton Avery ("Avery in Mexico," "Milton Avery and His Friends," "Milton Avery: Impressions of Mexico"), Paul Burlin ("Paul Burlin: Late Paintings"), Stuart Davis ("Stuart Davis: The Formative Years 1910-1930"), and Wolf Kahn's exhibition at the Arts Club of Chicago. Additional files cover exhibitions of from Germany ("Die Bruke: Major Painitngs and Works on Paper," "Selected German Prints," "German Prints 1900-1984: A Selected Survey"), Japan ("Techno-Metaphysics"), Korea ("Six Artists from Korea"), Mexico ("10 Artistas de Mexico"), and Canada ("Fifty Years of Canadian Landscape Painting: A Selection"). The gallery's participation in the ARCO (Feria Iinternacional de Arte Contemporaneo) art fair, the Art Dealers Association of America's "The Art Show," and the Messe Basel International Art Fair are also documented. Other significant exhibitions include "The Gloucester Years," "Pastel Anthonology II," and "Still Life Anthology."

did.unittitle: ARCO (Feria Internacional de Arte Contemporaneo) Art Fair (1992)
ARCO (Feria Internacional de Arte Contemporaneo) Art Fair (1993)
ARCO (Feria Internacional de Arte Contemporaneo) Art Fair, Organizing Committee

Art Dealers Association of America, "The Art Show" (1993-1996)
"Die Brucke: Major Paintings and Works on Paper", "Selected German Prints" (1992)
"Fifty Years of Canadian Landscape Painting: A Selection" (1987)
Wolf Kahn, Arts Club of Chicago (1981)

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: The files are arranged alphabetically by artist surname.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Artists' files consist mainly of correspondence with galleries and patrons regarding the artists and their work, and with many artists. The files on Milton Avery include documents for the Milton Avery Trust and writings about Avery. Jose de Rivera's files include preliminary writings by Dore Ashton for the book Jose de Rivera Constructions. Other artists' files are found for Max Beckmann, Charles Biederman, Martin Chirino, Jimmy Ernst, Janet Fish, Philip Grausman, Roy Gussow, Hans Hokanson, Angelo Ippolito, Rueben Kadish, David Lund, Gabor Peterdi, David Saunders, Sandy Walker, and Elbert Weinberg.

did.unittitle: Bolotowsky, Ilya, Trois Anges Ltd. Graphics Contract
De Rivera, Jose, Documents on Book Constructions
De Rivera, Jose, Library of Congress Copyright Office
De Rivera, Jose, Writings by Others
De Rivera, Jose, Writings by Dore Ashton

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The bulk of the series consists of sales and operations ledgers. Also included are files for artists contracts, documents regarding the Instituto de Artes Graficas de Caxaca/Francisco Toledo Non-Profit, and the London Arts Group.

did.unittitle: Instituto de Artes Graficas de Caxaca/Francisco Toledo Non-Profit

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Printed materials consist of exhibition catalogs and exhibition announcements.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Two scrapbooks contain clippings, certificates, photographs, and other printed material.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Photographic negatives of artwork are found here. A majority are labeled with the artist's name.
